About the Canadian Aviation Safety Board which is a matter of great concern to my hon. friend, he ought to know that we do not set up investigation offices as a matter of prestige but on the basis of operational needs. The services connected with the Canadian Aviation Safety Board are all located in the National Capital Region. The vast majority of agencies directly concerned are located there as well. The staff already consisted of people working in the region for Transport Canada. For all these reasons, it was and still is preferable to have the office in Hull, and I might remind the Opposition that Hull is located in Quebec, contrary to what I think the newspapers were saying or almost said.
I repeat, this is all part of the new framework we want to give this Government: the administrative consistency that will allow us to keep the promises we made that can be realized within a reasonable length of time, all of which we would have been unable to do if we had not acted to correct a situation that has been deteriorating for so long and which the previous Government should have corrected when it was time to do so.
My hon. friend has been referring constantly to VIA Rail. I might remind him, in connection with these "savage cuts"- quite an eloquent turn of phrase, I might add-that a committee was formed by the Hon. Minister of Transport (Mr. Mazankowski) to examine the issue of VIA Rail and will be expected to report. I can confirm what I said in Sherbrooke at a meeting where the Hon. Member was not invited, because we assumed that his constituents were very well informed, that they had told him about their concerns, and that the Hon. Member would surely take the trouble to pass their recommendations on to us. In this context, 1 said that I was in favour of restoring the Montreal-Atlantic route, and I want to repeat here in the House that if our present information is confirmed, I will make sure this is done, if it is in my power to do so.
You seem to be very worried about the Crow Rate. I would ask the Hon. Member for Shefford (Mr. Lapierre) to let us settle our own arguments. They will have their hands full with their own debate on the issue among the Members of the Opposition.
I admit I was somewhat taken aback by the vehemence of the comments made by the Member for Cape Breton-Rich-mond East (Mr. Dingwall). I wonder where he was when the former Government was administering this country. I wonder whether he was part of that Government that managed to accumulate this incredible, astronomical deficit we have now inherited. He should have realized that accumulating deficits could only lead to further expenditures which eventually must be answered for.
When your Government was in power, spending was done in such a haphazard fashion that all services in this country were in danger of being affected. I have been listening very carefully over the past few days to the questions being directed to the Minister of Employment and Immigration (Miss MacDonald). I admit I am rather amazed that people should be surprised at a situation they have done nothing to prevent. The big thing now is the universality of social programs. Unemployment has
been with us for longer than two months, much longer. You people were personally responsible for raising the number of unemployed workers in this country to 1,500,000, and you certainly cannot lay the blame at the doorstep of a Government that has been in power for only two months.
The country's economic situation is incredible, but here again, this did not happen in two months. A Government's financial credibility is not created in two months. It is based on situations that have been going on for years, and the previous Government did not have the political courage to deal with them when it was time to do so. I have the impression, especially since the statement by the Hon. Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson), that you are really blaming us for having had the political courage to take the action required to deal with unemployment with our own money and not other people's money. I repeat, Mr. Speaker, it may be my inexperience because nine months ago, I was, like most Canadians, watching what the Government was doing and wondering when it was all going to end. Maybe that is why I fail to understand why they did not act far more quickly than we must do now to correct situations that have brought this country to the brink.
Mr. Speaker, two weeks ago I travelled through Quebec, and though it is not typical of the situation in Canada as a whole, I did get a good idea of what Canadians expect of their transport facilities. I appreciate the vision offered earlier by my colleague, the Minister of Transport (Mr. Mazankowski), and I believe that the expectations of Canadians are along those lines. After realizing the seriousness of our present financial situation, I think we must have, and 1 did so emphatically to my fellow citizens and compatriots, made it clear that the Government had to rethink its expenditure plan, not to make cutbacks but to do what must be done within the transportation network. The needs are considerable and expectations are not necessarily the same. For instance, the Montreal area and the Gaspe do not have the same needs, so our response to those needs cannot be the same in each case, but we will have to respond with the funds at our disposal. In this connection, Quebecers, and I would extrapolate to include all Canadians, are now able to tell the Government they are prepared to support the redeployment of expenditures that is essential if we are to cope with all the needs identified within the transport sector.
I am surprised, in a way, when I analyze the total cutbacks for Transport: $287.1 million. The VIA Rail cuts, for instance, which were so vehemently criticized and commented upon, will be mostly obtained by reducing costs charged to VIA by the other two railway companies, by reducing operating costs, by a new investment strategy and by a new rate strategy. How can anyone say these measures as a whole will result in drastic cuts in service to Canadians? That is just not the case. I said earlier that we would be taking steps to restore the Atlantic service, that is, Montreal-Halifax, and also, if possible, the Toronto-Havelock and Edmonton-Vancouver routes.
Once again, within that structure, I think it is possible to do it, but certainly not in accordance with the financial criteria of the previous government, but rather by keeping in mind the
November 21, 1984

funds at our disposal. It was easy enough to spend money every which way, so much so that they could at least have maintained the services needed by the people. The CN budget has also been reduced by $46.8 million, but that is just a bookeeping measure. For three years now the Auditor General has been asking the government to recover that money which was in fact an overpayment, but no action was taken. Capital projects will be rescheduled and that will enable us to save $51 million, not to mention $23.5 million for transportation services and $34.6 million in air transportation and air cargo taxes. I rather doubt that air travellers will go broke if we raise from 8 to 9 per cent the tax on airplane tickets, which amounts to about $1 or $2. I think the people who use that means of transportation can more easily afford it.
Mr. Speaker, given the current situation after two months, I think I was quite justified in welcoming the statement made by the Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson). 1 said earlier that a lot of political courage was and is still required to assume responsibility for setting our financial house in order. Members of the Opposition can say what they like, but we as a party firmly believe, as the Minister of Finance, the Prime Minister and others have stated, that we will be able to restore the economic climate needed in Canada and to provide the services we are expected to offer.
Mr. Speaker, how easy it is to turn a blind eye to reality, easier still than spending money. The most challenging endeavour is to get some sort of order in our expenditures and to do what the Canadian people have elected us to do. It was on September 4 that we heard the clearest response to our promises and commitments to rationalize public outlays in 1984. That is why we are here and we intend to continue along those lines.

Mr. Speaker, I am particularly glad to see the Minister of Transport (Mr. Mazankowski) and the Minister of State responsible for the Canadian Wheat Board (Mr. Mayer) here this afternoon because I think they can make good use of many of the remarks I am going to make. These are issues which have affected the northwestern area of British Columbia for a long time.
First, I want to touch on what the Minister had to say regarding the possible joint federal-provincial agreement on the Yellowhead highway. I hope that his remarks this afternoon will apply to Yellowhead 16 between Prince George and Prince Rupert. I would like to spend a few moments commenting on a major transportation bottleneck starting to raise its ugly head on the north coast of British Columbia. It arises from an agreement made on April 18, 1977, between Ottawa and Victoria, an agreement which has never really been lived up to by British Columbia. In fact, it has been broken in Clause 4(2), as I will point out in a moment. The docket number is 104897, and it was signed by Mr. Bennett and Mr. Lang some seven years ago now. Clause 4(2) says that the Province agrees that in accepting the subsidy from Canada, as provided herein for ferry and coastal freight and passenger service in British Columbia coastal waters, it will assure reasonable and adequate service and appropriate supervision thereof. I think the background is well known by the Minister of Transport (Mr. Mazankowski), but there is a very appropriate quote taken from a Library of Parliament study I had done some time ago. It says that the reasons for withdrawing the subsidy are cited in the following. Many years ago we had Northland Navigation which had a number of coastal freighters that operated in and out of the smaller coastal communities, out of Prince Rupert and down the coast, and provided both passenger and freight transportation. I think this quotation indicates what the Government of that time thought would occur but of course never did occur. It says:
November 21, 1984

However, Transport Minister Otto Lang followed up by refuting that the withdrawal of the subsidy would either reduce services to northern B.C. communities or distort rates. The decision to lift the aid, he said, was taken after talks with the B.C. Government and various shipping companies in the province had revealed that the services would not be impaired by this action. These companies were interested in expanding their operations in northern B.C. he added. The removal of the subsidy would end what he described as 'present inequities,' and put non-subsidized carrier in better competitive positions to serve these communities.
What has happened, Mr. Speaker, as I am sure the Minister is well aware, is that the service between Prince Rupert and Port Hardy is now going to be cut down to once every two weeks. That means everyone in northwestern British Columbia who wants to go to Vancouver will have to drive 1,000 miles. That is 1,000 miles back and forth, particularly in the winter when the new twice a month scheduling is going to come in. In fact, as my colleague from Comox-Powell River knows very well, it eliminates regular ferry routing in and out of the community of Bella Bella and the linkage of course to Bella Coola and other communities.
We, and the Minister of Transport, have to look carefully at what the Alaskans are doing. They are bringing their state ferry service down into Hyder, a community of 200 on the north coast of British Columbia. They have recognized the economic viability of bringing their ferry service in to allow loopings for transport. I am glad to see the Minister of State for Tourism (Mr. McMillan) here because it is important that he be involved in studying how this agreement, signed by Canada and the Province of British Columbia, should be renegotiated. We should have looping ferry service going from Stewart to Kincolith to Port Simpson and back into Prince Rupert. We should maintain the barge service which regularly goes from Prince Rupert to Masset, providing an opportunity for propane and other commodities to be moved without having to have the driver and the tractor on board. You can put a drop trailor on and move it to the Queen Charlotte Islands. We must also maintain the regular passenger service between Prince Rupert and the Queen Charlotte Islands.
The federal Government, through this agreement, has now given over $70 million to Bill Bennett. Bill Bennett is shuffling that money into general revenues. This year, in excess of $14 million goes to the Province of B.C. The B.C. Government is on the record as saying that the whole cost, including depreciation on the vessels, salaries, and everything you can imagine, is $10 million. They are actually making a net benefit. Ottawa now pays entirely for the north coast service, and Bennett takes a $4 million cut and puts that into south coast services.
If a community like Hyder with 200 people can have the Alaska state ferry service regularly, why cannot a community like Stewart, with 2,000 people, be hooked into the system? Other smaller communities could be hooked into the system. The little passenger vessels from Port Rupert out of Port Simpson and Kincolith are unsafe. I can say quite honestly in the House that I fear there will be drownings. That vessel is not large enough. We have just lost a number of lives. It is
Supply
endangering the lives of those people who must take those routes.
I know the Minister is seriously interested in this. He said earlier today that he is going to be meeting with officials in B.C. to deal with it. The clause of which the Minister should make use from docket 104897 is Clause 4(2). The Province of British Columbia is simply not living up to the original agreement, and that contract and clause can and should be reopened for negotiation.
My second point is in terms of VIA Rail. As the Minister knows, we have seen an erosion over a number of years to the point where now fewer and fewer people take VIA Rail from Prince Rupert to small communities such as Usk or Cedarvale. There is really no other way either for freight or for passengers to get in and out of those communities. It is a real, identifiable need. However, it has become a self-fulfilling prophecy. When you downgrade the service and make it less accessible, people will find other ways. If one can only catch the train Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays, and one wants to buy groceries on Wednesdays, one must find some other way. Over time, the number of people using the service naturally declines. Then VIA can say that this route no longer has the kind of passenger utilization that makes it a viable service. That, of course, leads to greater and greater cuts.
I received a letter in March of this year from the Minister's Department saying that, because of Expo '86, the new prototype equipment may well be identified for use on the Prince George to Prince Rupert run. That is one of the most beautiful areas of the country. It has great potential for hooking into the kind of offshore tourist traffic that we have historically seen in Banff and Jasper. We could get the type of routings which would allow people to take circle tours. They could take VIA to Prince Rupert, whether from Edmonton or from Montreal. Having arrived there, they could take the Alaska state ferry service or the B.C. coastal ferry service. All of these services are interlinked. As one part of the over-all transport sector erodes, we lose the opportunity to upgrade other parts of that sector to bring more growth and tourists to northern British Columbia, an area which has been identified by many studies as having great potential in that respect.
My third point this afternoon, Mr. Speaker, is with regard to the Prince Rupert elevator. The Minister of Transport has already responded to the subject today, but I would like to give a very brief overview of what has happened in Prince Rupert. In 1979, the Minister signed what I believe he felt in good faith was a very good agreement. Ultimately, the people of Canada put about $30 million into the infrastructure costs at Wrigley Island for the new grain elevator, which is now very near completion. However, Prince Rupert Grain I has a very unique ability to load very rapidly a lot of the small Pacific Rim freighters that come in. TThat is not to say that the new elevator cannot do that. That is a very popular route for vessels from China and a lot of other Pacific Rim countries. That is not a state of the art elevator, but it can unload boxcars. In recent years it has set records, year after year, moving more than 1 million metric tonnes at a time. Last year it moved 15

per cent of the West Coast grain that was moved out of this country.
I am glad to see the Minister conferring with the Minister of State responsible for the Canadian Wheat Board (Mr. Mayer). I am also glad to see the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) listening. This is important.

speechtext: This is more attention than you have ever had.

That is right. The Minister did a good job. The Prime Minister should know that. The only Tory who could ever get elected in Prince Rupert is the Minister of Transport, but fortunately he is going to stay in Vegreville.
That same year, as the Minister responsible for the Wheat Board will know, $100 million in surge capacity was identified as needed for Prince Rupert. That money was starting to be put in place. I agree that the potential for the old elevator for surge capacity is limited. The Minister has already written to me about that and I recognize it. However, there is a real social and export need in terms of the good faith of the people of Prince Rupert. They did not expect to lose any jobs out of this. They expected to gain some. As it stands now, of the 100 grain jobs in Prince Rupert, we lose 75. That is a net loss of about $6 million a year to the City of Prince Rupert. To a small community, that is a huge loss. To small business the roll-over dollars are very high. For about $25 million the docking and galleries can be repaired. That would not make it a state of the art elevator, but it would be a good functioning system.
Farmers make 30 cents more a bushel shipping out of Prince Rupert. Small freighters save 500 navigation miles each way sailing from Prince Rupert to the Orient rather than from Vancouver. The Orient is very rapidly becoming our principal trade partner in terms of grain movement. Therefore, there are good, sound reasons why this elevator should remain open, hopefully with two shifts, maybe with three. I see the Minister of Transport and the Minister responsible for the Wheat Board smiling. 1 know they are going to move on it very soon. We have got it. That is good.

That is right. We can move some pelletized material. We can move some alfalfa and some of those more exotic feed stocks through there. I still think-and I think the Ministers will agree if they look at the 1979 report of the Wheat Board-that there is potential to keep it going. The Tories believe in competition. It may well be that Prince Rupert would be better off with some competition. I may not want Cargill or some of the other heavies in there, but needless
to say, I do not think the consortium has a gilt-edged requirement for having a monopoly on the part of Prince Rupert in terms of grain sales and movement.
The federal Government used to own that elevator. I must remind the Minister of Transport that he gave it to the corsortium for a buck. That is a pretty good deal for a $50 million elevator. Prince Rupert lost 75 jobs out of the deal. I know that the Minister will deal with it expeditiously.
My fourth point is with regard to the Digby Island airport. When you buy a ticket from CP Air that says you are going to Prince Rupert, you land on an island in the middle of the Hecate Strait. You get off to find there is nothing there and you wait for half an hour. You get on a privately operated bus on Transport Canada land. You drive down to a landing wharf operated by the Port of Prince Rupert. You then get on a ferry owned by the city, and the driver comes around and is forced, because of corporate regulations, to extort $6 from you. You have flown on that plane supposedly to go to Prince Rupert but you have to go through all this hassle.
I think the Minister of Transport needs to look at the brilliant options I have brought forward, such as for Transport Canada to operate some kind of hovercraft or ferry system that could be used for search and rescue. That is one module option. The other option, with the possibility of the LNG at Port Simpson, is for the Minister to move some money for the connection of Digby Island on to the peninsula and back across the Rapids and into the City of Prince Rupert. These are options that are not too expensive and would provide for greater and easier access between the city and Digby Island. Things are coming to a crunch. The ferry is wearing out. People's patience is getting thin. Every year when we use the system it has gone up another buck. Pretty soon it will be $200 to fly from Prince Rupert to Vancouver and $300 to take the ferry.

We need to move on this. I know the Department of Transport has a responsibility in terms of finding some options and participating with the City of Prince Rupert, the Province of B.C., and some of the industries that are planning on coming into the area, so that we can get it off the ground.
Now let me deal with airports. Let me name some of the airports I have to fly in and out of, such as Sandspit, Prince Rupert, Terrace, Smithers, Watson Lake and Whitehorse. All these require some kind of additional navigational aids. Terrace is the most dangerous right now in that the number of days when jets cannot land there is very very high compared with any other airport in Canada. It is very important in terms of safety that there be additional navigational aids. The Sandspit airport and the Watson Lake airport are just long enough for Boeing-737 landings. The Prince Rupert airport is a large airport. It does not have great difficulties with navigational aid problems. Certainly Smithers, Terrace, Sandspit and Watson Lake require upgrading.
November 21, 1984

Next is search and rescue. The Department of Transport and the Department of National Defence are hopefully going to provide fairly shortly two new 400-class cutters, one for the Queen Charlottes and one to operate out of Bella Bella. I am sure the Minister is aware of the most recent loss of life, which was partly tied into a complex jungle of mistakes that occurred as a result of weather reporting systems, some of which were off the air and some of which were not reporting fully. One can only surmise from talking to a lot of fishermen who knew the fishermen who drowned that some of them were among the most careful fishermen that ever cruised the coast of British Columbia and who would never have gone out in the kinds of wind and weather that occurred. I know the need is there for a couple of 400-class cutters, particularly for the Hecate Strait, to a certain extent the Dixon entrance and the west coast of the Charlottes, but also going down into the Queen Charlotte Sound. There is a real, identified need for that size and class of vessel. The "123" operating out of Prince Rupert cannot go out in anything other than a light chop. The Derby is large enough to go out.
There is also the potential for the early signing of an agreement with the State of Alaska to combine our helicopter efforts by moving a helicopter from Comox either to Masset, where we have a DND base and from where a helicopter could operate, or out of Prince Rupert. Again we have some search capacity with Buffaloes and other fixed-wing aircraft. But what we really require is rescue capacity. We require helicopter rescue capacity. Most recently, George MacDonald, head of the Museum of Man in Ottawa, was rescued by the U.S. Coast Guard. The U.S. Coast Guard helicopters came and lifted the people out of the water before they drowned. In almost all situations now in the Dixon Entrance, the Hecate Strait and on the west coast of the Charlottes we rely upon the Americans. I think it is about time we moved one of those five choppers from Vancouver Island on to the north coast. This is identified in various transport reports and recommendations. At the same time we should rubberize and upgrade the Coast Guard helicopter that operates out of Prince Rupert which is not now able to rescue but is simply capable of search capacity.
I think I have covered a few things in terms of transport. I notice there is a little time left to me. I would like for a moment to come back to the question of marine transport. I think the Minister, in seizing himself of this matter in the next week or so, needs to know how to deal with Alex Fraser and Mr. Bennett on this issue. It is a long-festering one and one that I think has a solution. You cannot base the statutory mileage rate from Port Hardy to Prince Rupert, which is what the subsidizing formula is based on, and say that you can still consider it a highway if it operates only once every two weeks. It is a damn poor highway if that happens. If you closed the highway between here and Toronto and had it open only once every two weeks, it would not be much of a highway. We have to use that same argument with the Government in Victoria, that if the formula is based on statute miles between Port Hardy and Prince Rupert, then you have to operate it as a
Supply
highway linkage. Rather than forcing people to drive one thousand miles from Prince Rupert to Vancouver under very treacherous conditions, people should have access to that highway both for freight and for safe passenger movement. We should have a vessel moving out of Prince Rupert that links Kitimat to Prince Rupert to Kincolith to Port Simpson and to Stewart so we can get those little circles of tourist and localized movement that is safer than the kind of operation we now have. I am thinking particularly of the vessel now on the Prince Rupert-Port Simpson-Kincolith run which is totally inadequate. The previous vessel was barely adequate. This one is endangering lives. If the Government in Victoria proceeds to cut the Masset to Prince Rupert barge service, it will mean all of the explosives, propane and so on, will have to be put on the dedicated passenger run between Prince Rupert and the Queen Charlottes, and the whole system will have to be cleaned up.

Mr. Speaker, I rise with some reluctance because I think there is something in the tradition that once one has been defrocked, one should not write about what went on in the seminary. However, I should like to follow the example of my successor who maintained his continuing interest in the area of transportation.
This resolution is targeted at a very important question, that is, the impact of very severe and destructive transportation cuts on regional economic growth and development in the country. We have seen time and time again total insensitivity on the part of Conservative speakers to that fundamental issue. They have decided en masse, as if there were some kind of large Kool-Aid tank in Georgetown from which they are all drinking, to worship at the shrine of the deficit cut. It has been raised to the level of theology. It has become a matter of utmost and critical importance to them, almost as if the search for the Holy Grail was insignificant compared with this great magical search for the deficit cut, as if all will be solved by reducing the deficit.
The fact that this is challenged by a number of quite sound economic analysts does not seem to bother them very much. In their haste to cut the deficit, they are reaching into programs which are of vital importance to a wide variety of cities, towns and regions throughout Canada. This totally escapes them. They are so totally preoccupied with the kind of theology we have heard, that they are prepared to sacrifice the economic security, stability and potential of Atlantic Canada, the northern regions of Canada and western Canada.
I want to talk particularly about my own region. The best way to express what westerners think of the position taken by the new Government, which they rewarded with a great deal of election trust-and there is no doubt about it-would be to quote from an editorial appearing in the Manitoba Co-operator, which represents the largest number of farmers in the Province of Manitoba. The November 8 edition contained a blank message which read, "Dear Brian: Just thought we would drop a note to you and your Members of Cabinet to say
thanks for nothing". It continued in the same vein to say that westerners placed a certain amount of trust in the promises and commitments of the Government and looked vainly in the Throne Speech for some indication that those promises would be fulfilled. As the editorial said, they came up with nothing. There was nothing to respond to their needs. There was nothing directed toward them. Perhaps the greatest disappointment was in the area of transportation, the area where in some ways the most grand and eloquent promises were made. They were to freeze the rates. It is now November 21, and we have not seen hide nor hair nor sign of any indication that the Government is prepared to make any move in areas affecting the interests of farmers as they were promised by the Conservative Party. I am not saying that they were right, but that was their promise. If we begin to wonder why at times people become somewhat cynical, I think we have to look at the fact that a bald-faced, straightforward commitment was made in the famous Prince Albert statement. People have been looking in vain somewhere in the nooks and crannies of the various speeches, yet all they have heard is the Gregorian chant of Members of Parliament saying, "We must cut the deficit". That is their only answer to all that ails the world.

Let us deal in factual terms. We have had the setting up of another task force to study the problem, and a $93 million cut. That is the sum total of actions on the part of the Government in terms of VIA Rail. What was under way already was a major capital project, which committed $200 million over a five-year period to the modernization and re-equipping of VIA Rail. That was put on hold, that is the unstated message. We had already committed money to the establishment of four maintenance bases in Halifax, Montreal, Toronto and Winnipeg. We know why they would not stop the one in Toronto; we know where the Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson) is from. The reason why those maintenance bases were absolutely essential to the modernization of VIA Rail was that that was the way to bring down substantially the maintenance costs, which occupy about 40 per cent of the operating cost of VIA Rail. Those maintenance bases were already contracted and under way. This Government has put them in the deep freeze. As a result, the ability of VIA Rail to save substantial amounts of money on its operating budget have thereby been frustrated until we get to the commission's study.
That was not something that had to be frozen or held. It was a clear-cut investment in modernization to bring about a substantial reduction in the cost to the taxpayer. The Minister of Finance talks about bringing the cost of Government down, but what does he do? His Minister of Transport takes an action that will keep the cost way up. Do you call that good economics? Of all those new back-benchers who have come here waiting to save the world I ask whether cancelling an investment that will save money on operating costs is good economics.
We also talked about new equipment. The Minister of Transport might be good enough to confirm this because he has seen the document. Under way already was a plan to provide new locomotives for the Atlantic region. That has been put on hold. There was a plan to convert all the cars on the Atlantic track region to electrical upgrading. That was a commitment-

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport
subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-TRANSPORT BUDGETARY CUT-BACKS
speechtext: That was pie in the sky, and you know it.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-TRANSPORT BUDGETARY CUT-BACKS
speechtext: That was no pie in the sky. It was part of the capital budget of VIA Rail. I challenge the Member opposite and the Minister to show that that was pie in the sky. That was part of the capital budget of VIA Rail until it was put on hold by this Minister of Transport.

speechtext: For what year?

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S O. 62-TRANSPORT BUDGETARY CUT-BACKS
speechtext:
Beginning this year. In addition, we had reintroduced the new service between Winnipeg and Edmonton. We had made a commitment and a decision on the

November 21, 1984
Supply
reintroduction of the route between Edmonton and Vancouver. To provide for new equipment on that, we had leased new Amtrak trains, which are presently on the tracks operating between Winnipeg and Edmonton. I invite the Hon. Member for Regina East (Mr. de Jong) to ride on it some time. That is the way of testing the application, of developing new equipment under contract with Bombardier on which construction can start next year. I do not know where that is going. I strongly recommend to Members opposite who are vitally interested in the future of VIA Rail that they get to their Minister of Transport at the first opportunity in caucus and ask him to go ahead with the Amtrak experiment to see whether it is valid, then purchase the cars and get them on the track. That was already under way.
Furthermore, we had committed a major investment to the Cancar factory in the Thunder Bay constituency so that Canada will develop its own technology for short trains. We had an agreement between Bombardier and Cancar to develop that new research and development at the Thunder Bay plant so that we would have a new form of Canadian-made trains under development. That has been put on hold.
They cannot get up in this House and say, "We are the Party of progress", when decisions that have already been initiated have been put in the deep freeze, put on hold. There is nothing wrong with another action committee to study it. That is okay, but why frustrate initiatives already under way? Why delay? Why put back? Why retard? What is the value of that, especially when it comes to the vital question which every Conservative Member has spoken about, the need to get costs down? That was the intended purpose, to bring costs down.
Let me move to a different subject, the whole question of how we stimulate growth and competition. I agree with the Minister of Transport. Every Minister of Transport has said that the transport of people and goods is vital to the economic health of this country. There is no question that what is very important is that we establish a way of getting higher levels of productivity and lower costs.
To initiate that, last year we introduced a new airline policy to deregulate the airlines, to bring new competition into the system and to provide higher levels of productivity. From every statement that I have read, the Minister of Transport has agreed to go along with that policy. He is in agreement with the thrust of that airline policy which we established last year. I will take him at his word.
What disturbs me is that last year we had also started the deregulation of the trucking industry. We had unanimous agreement with all the provinces at a federal-provincial conference last spring. Every single province agreed that we undertake major changes and reforms in trucking regulations to change the onus of proof so there would not be that ability to frustrate any regulatory change. We had instructed public servants to prepare a plan of action that was to come before a meeting on September 15, where it would be ratified and the new regulations could be put in place.
What happened? The meeting of September 15 has come and gone. All we have, to quote from my friends in the
Manitoba Co-Operator, is nothing. We had made a decision. We had an agreement from the provinces. We had developed a system that would have substantially brought down the costs of interprovincial and intercontinental trucking. In its economic statement, this Government lauded the concept of deregulation and more competition. However, it has put on hold a decision that had already been negotiated and arrived at and was already to be implemented.
How do you decide whether this Government is serious in its commitment to the Canadian poeple or economic reform and adjustment when it already had a ready-made package handed to it? It was a gift to them, something they could have put into place right away. For reasons that maybe are academic preoccupations, they have to restudy everything. They have put it on hold. As a result, I am afraid that it will become unravelled. We will find that the agreement we have already received will not be implemented. We will have set the clock backwards in enabling the federal and provincial governments to undertake an effective form of cost reduction at higher levels of productivity.
Some of my colleagues have pointed out that we want to improve our export capability and our cost performance by reducing the cost of transportation. That is a very laudable, very important, objective. What has this Government done in its economic statement? It has added close to $700 million in hidden taxation, mostly on the backs of small business people and particularly in the realm of transportation. While we were attempting to get costs down through deregulation, the Minister of Transport has added substantially to the user costs in our airports. He has brought in airport fees and is now talking about imposing fees on the transportation of cargo.
That is a good bureaucratic answer, but what really amazes me is that when the Minister of Transport was occupying the role of critic on this side of the House, in fact as recently as three months ago, he was arguing for a major change in airport pricing so that we could start decentralizing the ownership and control of airports. That was an important objective.
What does he do instead? He raises the cost. As a result, he is going to provide a countervailing force to the dergulatory impact that we have by increasing costs both to the passenger and to the cargo user.
By what form of logic does a government that is attempting to bring about a transportation system, which is a service industry to enable passengers and shippers to move quicker and faster and at lower costs and therefore expand the marketability, increase the cost of transportation by adding a user fee? That is not good economic sense.
Once again we are filled with a series of contradictions, wrapped in an enigma, all sort of bubbled up in a pile of rhetoric about the great new economic revolution that the Conservative Party is about to perpetrate upon the Canadian people. Instead, they are victimizing them. They are adding to their costs. They are providing a dampening effect on the ability of the business community to have lower cost transportation and, therefore, providing a reduction of growth, not an enhancement of growth.
November 21, 1984

That is the kind of economic analysis that Members opposite should apply, rather than simply standing in Pavlovian fashion worshipping at the Minister of Finance's icon that deficit cutting is the only thing that counts. They should peruse that document and realize that there are substantial fallacies in their economic analysis. Nowhere is that more important and more clear than in the area of transportation.
